image.altText: A composite picture of a brother and sister as children and as adults.

props.synopsis: Would you go into business with a sibling? From a winery to cheesemakers, these Tasmanian entrepreneurs have had a crack, and it's paying off.

title.children: This brother and sister bought a farm together. Here's how they made it work

image.altText: An aerial shot shows rows of houses.

props.synopsis: Property investors in New Zealand have had several years with a reduced ability to claim their interest payments as a tax deduction, but the new Coalition government has brought it back.

title.children: In NZ, negative gearing was slashed years ago. This is what happened to first home buyers

image.altText: Bunnings store sign

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian woman who worked in administration for the Central Highlands Council has been sentenced to 18 months home detention after defrauding the council of more than $130,000 through personal purchases from Bunnings, Harvey Norman and a liquor store for almost a decade.

title.children: Woman sentenced to home imprisonment after using council money to buy $135k worth of household, hardware and other items for herself

image.altText: An animated graphic of two people (silhouetted) standing with three large radomes in the distance.

props.synopsis: In the 1960s Alice Springs saw an economic lifeline when America promised to build a space base on the edge of town. But once its bizarre, oversized golf ball-like structures were built, mysterious things started happening.

title.children: US spies in the Australian outback – the story of Pine Gap is one of don't ask, don't tell

image.altText: Two women at a press conference.

props.synopsis: Speaking on behalf of some of the victim-survivors, their families and whistleblowers who engaged with Tasmania's child sexual abuse commission of inquiry, Katrina Munting called on the state government to offer more support for victim-survivors and to respond more quickly to the commission's recommendations.

title.children: Sick leave used up, overlooked for jobs. Victim-survivors at Tasmania's child sexual abuse inquiry say fallout is 'immense'

image.altText: Three unidentifiable people sit in a darkened room.

props.synopsis: The parents of a 10-year-old boy who was under the care of the WA Department of Communities when he took his own life on Saturday speak of the moment they were told their son had died, and why they feel he has been swept "under the rug".

title.children: 'It bloody hurts': Parents of 10yo who took his own life in state care speak of devastation, hit out at government

image.altText: People hold signs that say 'down with Israel' at a protest rally

props.synopsis: The comments came after Iran signalled earlier it had no plans to retaliate against Israel.

title.children: Iran says it will respond at 'maximum level' if Israel plans further attacks

image.altText: Benjamin Netanyahu in front of an Israeli flag

props.synopsis: The events of the past week have put the Middle East in a strange and uncertain space. Neither Iran, nor Israel would benefit from the prospect of an all-out war with the other, but equally, neither seems prepared to back down.

title.children: Iran and Israel are in a dangerous game of chicken, with a deadly prize for winning

image.altText: dark ominous clouds over houses in the suburb of beechwood as a storm from approaches

props.synopsis: Australia's weather will serve up a smorgasbord of variability this weekend, with an expected drenching for the east, wintry nights in the southern states and ongoing heat in the west.

title.children: East coast to soak over the weekend amid possible cyclone, frosty south — and endless WA heat

image.altText: Woman looks solemn while standing at beach.

props.synopsis: High inflation means many workers' HECS debts are growing faster than they can pay it off. It shows why calls for change have grown so loud that the prime minister has all but confirmed there will be HECS relief in the budget, national education and parenting reporter Conor Duffy writes.

title.children: Large HECS debts used to be rare. Now thousands of us owe more than $60,000

image.altText: A female boxer is in the ring sparring by herself.

props.synopsis: Many athletes don’t eat enough food for the amount of energy they’re outputting – and that can lead to serious health issues and affect their performance.

title.children: Why eating enough when exercising is so important

image.altText: A police officer uses a fire extinguisher in a park

props.synopsis: A man has set himself on fire outside the New York courthouse where Donald Trump's historic "hush-money" trial is taking place.

title.children: Man rushed to hospital after setting himself on fire outside court where Donald Trump is on trial

image.altText: New King Island ferry John Duigan

props.synopsis: It is normally lush and green, but King Island is drought-stricken and its farmers are calling for help to ship their cattle and sheep north to the mainland.

title.children: King Island desperate to ship cattle to Victoria as drought takes hold, Premier looks into route

image.altText: Close up of Brittany Higgins with her head down.

props.synopsis: Bruce Lerhmann's defamation case has exposed a continuing hostility to women in the broader Australian community which has seen women too eagerly cast as liars, whatever the nature of the issue that has brought them to public attention.

title.children: The uncomfortable truth of how our political leaders responded to Brittany Higgins's rape allegation lingers

image.altText: Composite image of the front of Strathfield Plaza in 1991 and Westfield Bondi Junction in 2024.

props.synopsis: In 1991, seven people were killed when a man entered Strathfield Plaza with a knife and a semi-automatic weapon. For some, the Bondi Junction stabbing attack was a traumatic reminder.

title.children: A man murdered seven people at a Sydney shopping centre in the 90s. Three decades on, the trauma remains

image.altText: Michelle sits in shadows to protect her identity.

props.synopsis: Coercive control will become a criminal offence in Queensland next year, carrying a maximum sentence of up to 14 years in jail, but survivors fear police won't be equipped to respond.

title.children: 'They just didn't want to go there': A woman subjected to coercive control for years says police will struggle under new laws

image.altText: A man sitting in a doctor's surgery with a head wound a blood around the nap of his t-shirt.

props.synopsis: The attack on a Cambodian-Australian visiting his homeland sets a worrying precedent according to community leaders and prompts activists to cancel upcoming travel plans.

title.children: 'It's really, really frightening': Activists cancel trips to Cambodia after Melbourne man brutally assaulted

image.altText: japanese citizens stand with a banner

props.synopsis: Six couples are suing the Japanese government for the right to use different surnames. With the support of big business, there is now growing pressure to allow more options.

title.children: 'I've never thought of erasing my name': Japan mulls changes to surname laws

image.altText: A man smiles at the camera

props.synopsis: Taylor Martin stood aside from the party room last year after a woman, who he had been in a relationship with, lodged a formal complaint to the NSW Liberal Party.

title.children: NSW Liberal MP expelled from party following investigation triggered by complaint

image.altText: A close up of a man in a suit wearing sunglasses

props.synopsis: 'The Mooch' got up close and personal with Donald Trump during his brief time as White House communications director. Now he's one of his biggest critics.

title.children: Anthony Scaramucci worked in Trump's White House for 11 days. He's disturbed by what he saw

image.altText: Man standing at TechnologyOne office in Victoria.

props.synopsis: Behnam Roohizadegan thought he'd won a record $5.2 million payout against publicly-listed company TechnologyOne, but now the case is being retried, dragging on years of anguish he claims he has suffered at the hands of the big corporation.

title.children: Retrial set for TechnologyOne case that set record for $5.2m unlawful dismissal payout

image.altText: A young woman and her dog sit next to each other on a beach.

props.synopsis: Marcia Ryan was 33 when she disappeared in 1996, her car abandoned by the side of the Princes Highway in Victoria. Her family has never given up hope of finding out what happened to her.

title.children: New clues unearthed in 28yo mystery of missing woman Marcia Ryan

image.altText: Raindrops on fallen leaves.

props.synopsis: The first signs of autumn have arrived, and I'm not quite ready for the grey days and the end of long evenings in a garden to which I give little but always rewards me with a deep green solace.

title.children: That radical change from summer towards autumn happened in a moment. I'm not ready

image.altText: man in thick, black rimmed glasses in suit with Australian and Aboriginal flags in background

props.synopsis: 'We shouldn't put up with it': head of the Family Court says the frequency of violence against women in Australia is a 'national disgrace'.

title.children: Chief Justice of the Family Court urges men to call each other out about violence against women

image.altText: Alice and her husband sit on the couch holding their young children.

props.synopsis: According to the Australian Medical Association's latest report card the ACT has the worst wait times at emergency departments in the country. The government says things are getting better but Alice's experience is still far from unusual.

title.children: Alice and her newborn baby waited five hours to be seen at Canberra Hospital, before learning he was in heart failure

image.altText: A blue and black stripped cuckoo bee on a yellow flower

props.synopsis: While there is no shortage of research on European honey bees and the various threats to their survival, experts fear a paucity of data on native species means they are quietly dying out.

title.children: Could native bees be driven to extinction while scientists' eyes are elsewhere?

image.altText: Three composite photos of pop singer taylor swift

props.synopsis: Taylor Swift's 11th studio album, The Tortured Poet's Department, has dropped and her fans are feeling a lot of things. Then the pop star managed to pull off a double surprise — sending the internet into meltdown.

title.children: Taylor Swift's new album is actually two new albums, and the internet has lost it

image.altText: Two women's soccer teams and mascots walking out to play a match.

props.synopsis: Stadium construction is a costly exercise, especially for cash-strapped sporting leagues and clubs, leading to a growing number of cities and teams around the world exploring a potentially vastly cheaper alternative — so-called 'modular stadiums'.

title.children: Stadiums can be political footballs, but could built-to-order grandstands solve the problem?

image.altText: Whitney and Danielle Yunupiŋu hold a yelllow football and look across the camera while smiling against a backdrop of trees.

props.synopsis: Cultural 'shame' can hold Yolŋu women back from playing footy in north-east Arnhem Land. Now women and girls want their brothers' backing in the momentum to restart a local league.

title.children: In a quest to play footy, these Arnhem Land women want their brothers' support

image.altText: A middle-aged woman with a brown bob haircut smiles as she hugs a large mushroom formation in a field.

props.synopsis: Foraging for food is an innate behaviour in humans and something our ancestors have been doing for millennia – and fungi are among the most commonly sought-after provisions. But how dangerous is it to forage for wild mushrooms in Australia?

title.children: What to know if you're planning on foraging for fungi

image.altText: a new soutyh police sign and a security camera

props.synopsis: At least nine other people across Australia have been charged with the same offence as the 16-year-old accused of carrying out the Sydney church stabbing.

title.children: A 16yo has been charged after the Sydney church stabbing. Here's how Australia's terrorism laws apply

image.altText: Sign on a chicken-wire fence saying danger, with big battery and wind turbine in the background

props.synopsis: For decades a backer of so-called cost reflective power pricing, the Australian Energy Regulator has acknowledged major problems with the roll-out of complex tariffs.

title.children: Power companies on notice as energy regulator flags serious concerns over complex pricing

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and a flower garland around his neck holds a microphone and points upwards.

props.synopsis: This election is the first in Solomon Islands since Manasseh Sogavare struck a security pact with China in 2022.

title.children: Solomon Islands pro-China PM Manasseh Sogavare retains his seat as counting continues

image.altText: He Jie

props.synopsis: Organisers of the Beijing Half Marathon apologise and revoke the placings of the first four men across the line, after an investigation finds the place-getters let China's He Jie win.

title.children: Beijing Half Marathon champion He Jie has medal taken away after rigged finish

image.altText: The cover for What Lies Beyond the Veil is left, with A Court of Thorns and Roses, centre, and Fourth Wing, right.

props.synopsis: We've got you with recommendations for eight series that will make you forget Rhysand ever had your heart — spice rating included.

title.children: Eight smutty fantasy series to fill the Sarah J. Maas-sized hole in your heart
